India’s  economic  growth  over  the  last  two  decades  has  been 
accompanied  by  rising  fiscal  imbalances.  The  deteriorating  fiscal 
position since fiscal year (FY) 1998 has impeded both central and 
state  governments  in  their  efforts  to  effectively  finance  desirable 
public  investment  and  provide  social  sector  expenditure  to  foster 
poverty reduction. To successfully achieve fiscal and governance 
reforms, the state governments must join the central Government 
in addressing fiscal imbalance problems as the states collectively 
account for about half of the country’s aggregate fiscal deficit.  
 
The Assam state government (ASG) faces fiscal and governance-
related  structural  problems;  its  limited  infrastructure  endowment 
lags most Indian states. The state’s fiscal position is weak due to 
stagnation  of  tax  and  nontax  revenues  and  growing  revenue 
expenditures.  ASG  must  also  contend  with  high  interest  debt, 
rising  government  wage  and  salary  expenditure,  and  pension 
liabilities.  The  several  public  sector  enterprises  (PSEs)  that  are 
loss  making  impose  a  considerable  budgetary  burden,  suppress 
competition, and deter private sector participation.  
 
ASG is therefore facing increasing fiscal stress from mounting and 
unsustainable  fiscal  deficits  and  concomitant  large  public  debt.

governance  reforms  to  promote  efficiencies  and  plug  leakages, 
deteriorating  fiscal  imbalances  and  governance  deficiencies  will 
increasingly  erode  physical  and  human  capital  expenditures  and

Sustainability of Recent Economic Performance. The recent economic performance 
of India has been impressive with gross domestic product (GDP) growth more than doubling to 
8.2% in fiscal year (FY) 2004 as compared with 4.0% in FY2003. The key question is whether 
this  high  growth  is  sustainable.  The  downside  risks  during  the  current  year  include  the  still 
inadequate progress in fiscal consolidation at the center as well as by the states.1 Inadequate 
fiscal  consolidation  by  the  states  has  the  potential  to  undermine  the  sustainability  of  recent 
economic  performance  and  the  delivery  of  promised  economic  prospects.  Given  the  state 
governments’ demands for funds, the national economy is  more prone to higher interest rates 
and to crowding out private investment. The high percentage of revenue deficit in the state fiscal 
deficit,2  primarily  due  to  wages,  salaries,  pensions,  and  interest  payments,  limits  government 
spending  on  education,  health,  and  infrastructure,  and  means  that  the  burden  of  fiscal  deficit 
correction  tends  to  fall  on  public  investment.  This  does  not  allow  government  to  address 
constraints to economic growth caused by inadequate infrastructure and poor social indicators.

45.  Medium-Term Fiscal Plan. Addressing ASG’s fiscal constraints requires the Program to 
set  the  foundation  stones  for  a  fiscal  responsibility  regime  that  introduces  key  fiscal  prudence 
checks and balances. A critical element is the formulation, adoption, and implementation of an 
MTFP.  An  MTFP  would  link  integrated  fiscal  and  governance  reform  measures  to  the 
achievement  of  fiscal  projection  target  outcomes  to  create  sustainable  fiscal  resources  over  a 
medium-term time frame.  
 
46. 
The  MTFP  fiscal  projection  targets  for  creating  sustainable  fiscal  resources  under  the 
Program are designed to achieve (i) at least two percentage points reduction in revenue deficit 
to revenue receipts ratio on average per annum from FY2005 to FY2009; (ii) a gradual increase 
in  the  capital  outlay  to  GSDP  ratio  from  1.5%  to  2.5%,  subject  to  absorptive  capacity;  (iii)  a 
sustainable  revenue  surplus  by  FY2008;  and  (iv)  a  significant  reduction  in  the  debt  to  GSDP 
ratio  from  40%  to  37%  by  FY2009.  The  MTFP  will  measure  projections  through  a  single 
indicator (revenue deficit to revenue receipts ratio). This indicator is proposed under the central 
Government’s Fiscal Reform Facility to monitor and evaluate overall reduction of fiscal stress by 
capturing  key  off-budget  impacts.  However,  since  Assam  is  a  Special  Category  State  with 
significant  dependence  on  the  central  Government  for  its  resources,  the  MTFP  should  also 
focus  on  multidimensional  fiscal  performance  indicators,  including  revenue  deficit  to  own 
revenue,  for  monitoring  and  evaluation  purposes.  These  reform  scenario  projection  targets, 
prepared  in  consultation  with  ASG  and  the  central  Government,  will  form  inputs  into  ASG’s 
FY2007  and  FY2008  budgets  in  the  context  of  a  medium-term  fiscal  consolidation  framework 
through FY2009. The MTFP is in Appendix 5, and the key assumptions underpinning the MTFP

PROGRAM BENEFITS, IMPACTS, AND RISKS 

111.  Overall. The Program is expected to yield material benefits to the population in Assam, 
including  the  36%  who  are  poor  by  supporting  (i)  the  generation  of  fiscal  space  for  increased 
spending  on  social  sector  expenditure  to  reduce  poverty  and  growth-inducing  capital 
expenditure  on  infrastructure;  (ii)  improved  fiscal  governance  for  effective  utilization  and 
prioritization  of  existing  resources  to  increase  GSDP  growth  and  reduce  poverty;  and  (iii) 
improvements  in  the  rationalization  and  quality  of  public  expenditure,  and  creation  of  an 
enabling environment for improved opportunities for sustainable employment and growth.   
 
112.  Creation of Sustainable Fiscal Resources. Benefits will accrue over the medium term 
linked  to  the  policy  matrix  and  the  MTFP.  Several  actions  under  the  policy  matrix  for 
subprogram  1  are  specifically  designed  to  create  benefits.  Thus,  the  various  deficit  reduction 
fiscal policy actions anchored by the MTFP and the restructuring of debt utilizing loan proceeds 
will enable an additional creation of fiscal space in a sustainable manner that can be utilized for 
targeted growth-inducing and poverty-reducing public expenditure.  
 
113.  Strengthened  Growth-Orientated  and  Poverty-Reduction  Projects.  The  benefit  of 
effective  utilization  of  additional  fiscal  space  for  poverty  reduction  and  growth  will  result  from 
subprogram  1’s  fiscal  governance  component  under  which  a  core  investment  program  will 
objectively prioritize capital outlay on development projects that have the most significant impact 
on poverty reduction or growth.  
 
114.  Strengthened ASG Operations. The core governance component of subprogram 1 will 
result  in  the  benefits  of  (i)  containment  of  staff  costs  in  the  interests  of  growth  and  poverty 
reduction focused public expenditure; (ii) a results-based, responsive, and performance-oriented 
state government; and (iii) the additional employment, growth, and income generation resulting 
from a public-private partnership. 
 
B. 

Impacts 

115.  Poverty Impact. The Program’s policy and institutional reforms are expected to overall 
have a positive impact on poverty reduction. The Program mitigates potential adverse poverty 
impacts  in  three  ways.  First,  in  terms  of  PSE  reform,  the  Program’s  support  for  closure  of  7 
PSEs will entail a VRS-SSN program. The closure of these PSEs will not lead to loss of regular 
employment as these units are already inoperative. Second, the Program will mitigate any short-
term  deterioration  of  household  spending  of  pensioners  by  containing  unfunded  pension 
liabilities in the long run on behalf of all government employees. In any event, the Program will 
not  affect  the  current  targeted  social  security  arrangements  for  the  poor,  such  as  old  age 
pensions.  Third,  the  Program  will  implement  a  user  fees  policy  only  after  a  careful  strategic 
review to assess possible adverse impacts on the poor in terms of access and affordability for 
the poor and targeted protection for the poor. A summary poverty reduction and social strategy 
is in Appendix 11. The matrix on poverty impact and mitigation assessment is in Supplementary 
Appendix G. 
 
116.  Environmental,  Involuntary  Resettlement,  and  Impact  on  Indigenous  People.  The 
Program will not have any direct or immediate environmental impacts (Supplementary Appendix 
H).  The  Program  will  help  implement  and  streamline  clear  application  of  existing  laws  against 
environmental pollution resulting from the public-private taskforce review of environmental laws,

rules,  and  regulations.  The  Program  does  not  trigger  ADB’s  involuntary  resettlement  and 
indigenous peoples’ policies. 
 
C. 

Risks 

1. 

The Program  

117.  Political Risks. Assam has a history of insurgency and law and order problems. Assam 
has experienced a series of political and social challenges during the last 5 to 6 decades. The 
state  has  shown  great  resilience  in  the  face  of  insurgency  accentuated  by  the  partition  of  the 
country  in  1947,  demographic  changes  and  reorganization  of  the  state  in  1972  against  a 
backdrop of economic deceleration. The Program is providing a complementary growth-oriented 
program to the steps already taken by ASG to contain insurgency and law and order problems 
through  the  Assam  Accord  of  1985  and  the  recent  Bodo  Accord  of  February  2003.  The 
Program’s  policy  actions  are  structured  through  first  and  incentive  tranches  to  achieve  critical 
results  early  given  the  state  electoral  calendar  in  2006.  In  addition,  the  accomplishment  of 
subprogram 1 policy actions will set the stage for deepening of policy reforms in subprogram 2 
after the state elections.   
 
118.  To  mitigate  the  risks  of  misinformation  and  lack  of  clear  communication  about  the 
implications  of  the  Program  to  key  stakeholders,  the  Program  includes  measures  to  build 
consensus and strong stakeholder support through a comprehensive communications strategy, 
including an annual Assam development forum.  
 
119.  Bureaucratic  and  Legislative  Risks.  The  Program  aims  to  increase  transparency 
through  fiscal  and  fiscal  governance  reforms;  and  enhance  government  performance, 
accountability, responsiveness, and vigilance through core governance reforms. Those opposed 
to  such  a  process  could  seek  to  impede  the  reforms  and  delay  legislative  enactment.  To 
mitigate such risks, strong ownership at the highest political and bureaucratic levels is built into 
the  Program  and  its  implementation  arrangements.  Key  institutional  actions  are  to  precede 
legislation.  In  addition,  capacity  building  and  public  awareness,  through  the  attached  Project, 
will help foster reform champions within the system. 
 

2. 

The Project

Institutional  Risks.  The  Program’s  comprehensive  nature  will  place  considerable 
demands on ASG’s weak institutional capacities. ASG has only limited experience with this type 
of fiscal and governance reform programs. To mitigate these risks, significant capacity building 
and systems support are built into the Program through the Project. In addition, the Project will

as shareholder, knew of the poor state of the financial affairs in the particular PSEs when these 
liabilities were incurred.

With 36.09% of its population below the poverty line, Assam has very high levels of income and human poverty, and a

The  Assam  Governance  and  Public  Resource  Management  Program  will  contribute  to  promoting  fiscal  stabilization 
and consolidation and improved governance. State finance reforms for fiscal stabilization will support additional fiscal 
resources that can be used for poverty-focused social sector expenditure and some user fee reforms enabling better
